Posted: May 9, 2014
												Had I written this review a week after buying Dustforce, the text box would have been filled only with the words  TOO SODDING HARD  in bold type. Now, after about 20 hours of playtime I can safely say that this game is really worth the effort.Dustforce is a single-player speedy platformer clean-‘em-up with resemblance to games such as Super Meat Boy. The aim of each level is to dash around cleaning the objective dirt off the various walls, floors and enemies in the fastest time possible, and by "enemies" I use the word very loosely. When you come across one of these dusty creatures you simply smack them a few times with your broom until they are thoroughly clean. The woodland animals then drop to the floor unharmed, which I find easier to live with than the Tomb Raider style destruction of wild animals; this way they’re just getting squeaky clean.At the end of each level you are presented with two ranks: one for completion and one for finesse. The aim is to get the highest rank in both areas by cleaning up all the scum in the level without breaking streak. When you do so, you get a key to a harder level. One of my favourite aspects of Dustforce is the menus, which are like independent levels where the goal is to find the actual levels of the game. All the game mechanics and physics are present here, so if you can’t access a level it’s either because you don’t have a key to it or you just suck. Another great part of the game is the replays that get uploaded at the end of each level and the scoreboard that is also shown, as it lets you know who’s the fastest duster in town. For most of the levels it’s a guy named Thor claiming #1, and by clicking next to his name you can watch Thor diving through the level.It’s a game I have 20 hours in and still believe I’ve only scraped the surface. If you do get round to playing this masterpiece beware of spikes, stone faces and the fact that you’re not Thor.

Posted: January 27, 2013
												I'm writing a review for this because I'm damn sure it doesn't get enough love. Out of any game on Steam, I'd say this is the most underrated game I've seen. It's got the smoothest, most in depth movement I've seen in a platformer. It's got a wide variety of levels, going from easy as hell to way beyound Super Meat Boy difficulty. This game is in my all time top 10. Great job Hitbox Team.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												Dustforce is an amazing platformer.  It feels, looks, and sounds extremely smooth and pleasent.  It's a score chase of sorts, where you can race for the best time, but I feel like I'm always trying to get the smoothest run possible, not the fastest time.  It's incredible in that you can fail over and over again and yet not feel frustrated.  And when you finally succed, you are rewarded by feeling completely amazing about a run you just made that never had any mistakes and looked super grateful.Of all the platformers I've played, I like Dustforce the most.  The music is absolutely perfect, the gameplay is extremely solid and consistent, and graphics are beautiful.  It also has multiplayer and a level editor!    The replayability is great too, because sometimes you just want to go back to old maps and perform them smoother than you could before.  I would rate Dustforce a 10/10.

Posted: January 11, 2016
												Dustforce is a really smooth platform game, with a big focus on stylish and fast ways to clear the levels. With an included level editor, and leaderboards available for all levels ever uploaded- it becomes a very competetive experience, especially since you can watch every (!) player's replay in-game. You can try to redo their runs and improve upon them- to climb the leaderboards, and feel like the king of the big internet arcade.The game itself is very challenging, but selfexplanatory and easy to learn. The progress you make as a player is always clearly visible and definitely satisfying. If you want online challenges- there's plenty available; if you want to play just for yourself- there are medals at the end of each level, to reward you with a bit of singleplayer experience.It's big, fun, and sometimes frustrating to play; but even if you can't get very far- there is always the great artstyle to gaze upon, and chill soundtrack to soothe your nerves (not to mention level editor, where you can make your own kind of experience).I love this game and I definitely recommend it; but it's hard for me to tell whether I like the game better, or just it's beautiful soundtrack (STRONGLY ADVISED TO PLAY THE TRAILER).

Posted: May 26, 2014
												A most enjoyable platformer that's equally pleasing in aesthetics, gameplay, and music. The (customizable) controls are limited in number so as not to be overwhelming, yet despite this the character actions, including inventive combos, are fun and enjoyable to watch. I absolutely LOVE the overall design/style of the game -- simple shapes, visually engaging worlds, and cool graphics -- and the soundtrack alone is worth the price tag (seriously, I'd be content with just listening to the soundtrack for hours; music can be a make-or-break deal for me in a game, and this one certainly delivers). My only complaint is that it's a *bit* difficult sometimes getting on ledges because of how the up button/control works in conjuction with jump, but that's a minor, more personal, issue. If anything, it makes the game more challenging, which is welcome in itself. For just $10.00, this thing is freakin' awesome. If you love platformers, fun and engaging environments, and awesome music, your money will not go to waste on Dustforce.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												No Frills, just good solid platforming. Precise timing and perfect execution are required to progress to the difficult levels.  If you want a casual platforming game look elsewhere, because this is for the people who want to punish themselves with retry after retry to get that "perfect" run.  It's frustrating at times, but just making it through one of the later levels feels like an accomplishment in itself.  First runs through levels are like platforming puzzles, and it's really fun to see the creative skills you learn to get through the more difficult sections.  There is something else here though, and I can't recommend this game without mentioning it.  This game has such a great flow to it that, along with the sweet soundtrack, put me in such a mood that hours in this game, even if those hours are re-dos all on one level, are super enjoyable.  Hitting all the dust on a run without slowing reminds me very much of hitting a platinum on trials evolution.  TL;DR If you enjoyed the difficulty of the hard levels of Super Meat Boy and/or Trials Evolution, then I would recommend this game.

Posted: October 30, 2014
												Dustforce is a well-constructed platformer that emphasizes precision in such a flowing manner that it's easy to feel like the technique required is more luck than skill. It isn't really a platformer for someone looking for a quick drive-by game, and while there are lots of technique intensive platformers this one definitely stands out. Going through the motions of the game and then watching replays of the top runs through each level makes it very easy for the player to feel very unskilled at the game. I think it's easy to have a love/hate relationship with the controls in the game. Be willing to change them to something more comfortable if you find their initial configuration unpleasant to work around. Try the game on a gamepad or arcade stick. They ARE responsive controls, but I know that I didn't feel like that immediately. Adapting to the idiosyncracies of a game makes it more intuitive and this game will most likely require some adaptation. The game physics and the controls will require precise timing and attention to detail to progress through it.The game looks fairly nice, and the soundtrack is beautiful. There's lots of levels to run through, and an editor if you like playing around with the tools.DO buy this game if you enjoy technical platformers with non-combat goals.Dustforce DX changed the layout of the levels a bit, and added different tutorial levels to explain a few techniques a little better. They're much better at teaching some of the techniques, but don't think of them as a barrier to the rest of the game. Go out and try a few of the levels and just run around the Nexus to get a feel for the game.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												Not only is the game absolutely amazing, but the soundrack is well worth listening to if you dislike platformers.Did you enjoy Super Meat Boy? Buy this. Just buy it. $10 is a bargain, it could easily be $20 and still worth your money. This game is essentially a Super Meat Boy style platformer, but with the more momentum based gameplay of N combined. If you look up Dustforce Thor, you can watch the YouTube video "All About Thor" and see what I mean. This game is all about skill, momentum, and score, where every time you play a level your rating is calculated at the end based on two factors: Completion, and Finesse. The rankings go D>C>B>A>S for both. You're aiming for S. Completion is based on how much of the dust in the level you actually picked up, and Finesse is based on a combo system in the game. If you either kill an enemy or pick up dust, you'll gain a number on your combo rating, going up for each consecutive dust within a certain amount of time, with the time resetting on pickup. A rather basic combo system. If you get hit, or die, you lose your combo, ruining your chance of getting an 'S' in Finesse. To get two S's for the level, you have to collect all of the dust, kill all the enemies, and do so whilst keeping your combo up throughout. If you get a "double S", you have essentially "beaten" the level, and I use the term beaten loosley because you will not have come close to the actually good players, and will be given either a Bronze, Silver or Gold key to unlock a different level with. There are also pre-unlocked levels which unlock at the beginning of the game automatically. If you beat a Pre-Unlocked level with an SS rank, you'll be given a bronze key. You can then use that key to unlock a different level, and if you beat a bronze-locked level, you get a silver key, silver levels give gold keys, and after you complete a Gold level you gain a Red key which is used in a hidden area within the main nexus hub world to unlock one of many doors, after all of which have been unlocked you finally get access to some of the hardest custom levels made before Dustforce DX came out which the devs kindly added here to the improved version. There is also a barebones combate system, consisting of light and heavy attacks, as well as a special attack gained after a 100 combo, executed by pressing light+heavy attack buttons simultaneuosly. These light combat mechanics allow you to take on the games many varied enemies. The "dust" you're picking up isn't always dust, either. There are 4 zones in the game; Forest, Laboratory, Industrial, and Abandoned. The last two aren't the real names but it works. In Forest, the dust is leaves. Laboratory has slime, industrial has garbage, and abandoned has... well, dust. If any of this sounds even remotely interesting, please google a high level gameplay video ad then contrast to a low level one to understand what I mean about skill being such a massive factor. Overall:Pros:-Amazing sountrack, worth listening to on its own-Momentum based gameplay feels great-High skill ceiling for lots of replayability-Incredibly tight controlls, which are necessary for a game like this-Wonderful art styleCons:-High skill floor, meaning a large barrier to entry-Incredibly difficult; now I love this so I won't dock points but many see it as a con, depends on your preference-Have to manually bind controls on controller, althogh no need for 3rd party appOverall:I would give dustforce a 10/10 score. Now why would I do that if I listed 3 cons? Well because difficulty doesn't matter in a review score, though should still be mentioned in the review itself, and because manuallybinding controls doesnt matter when you remember that everyone has a control preference and letting people figure theirs out instead of teaching them a control system and thus almost ubiquitously forcing them to relearn is a much much better alternative. Definitely buy this game if you're into difficult platformers. If not, sample the soundtrack, potentially give it a buy, and otherwise, move on.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Dustforce is a game about 4 heroic cleaners out to clean up some sort of sentient filth.  Leaves, dust and slime all coat the floors, walls and ceilings of each level and it’s your job to sweep, dust or vacuum it all away.  To do so requires precise, difficult control and levels are designed to be completed with finesse.  The game shines in its difficulty which drives the player to finish each level as quickly and elegantly as possible, striving for an elusive SS Rank.Dustforce is not a game without some fault, however.  The controller support is limited, requiring some menu fidgeting to get it to work and the d-input controls override the keyboard inputs.  The game also doesn’t do a great job of guiding the player or setting a level curve, despite the door and key mechanic for some of the harder levels.  But really, those are minor gripes.Despite its minor flaws, I’ve really been enjoying this game.  The beautiful visuals and vibrant music have quite a grip on me.  The animation uses a lot of fluid animation smears and the the music presents a feeling of adventure without being over the top.  It’s very relaxing, which can be very important when dealing with a particularly difficult run.One of the better mechanics also lies in the replay mechanic.  When looking at the leaderboard, simply click on any of the camera icons (including the one by your own run) to view a replay of that run in its entirety.  This is a cool way to see how your friends compare, how you can improve your own run and what the top players are doing to get such good runs.In the end, this game is fantastic, and somewhat reminiscent of something like N+ or perhaps even Super Meat Boy.  If you’re into that sort of tough platforming, Dustforce is worth your time and money.  And buy the soundtrack edition; it’ll save you a step later.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												This is not a game for the light-hearted. I'm being serious - if you want to get a perfect on all of the stages, you are going to need to set aside a significant chunk of time to devote to this. The way your janitor controls also takes some getting used to, you have to stop yourself from pressing the jump button one more time when you get started, and the precise timing may be off-putting. However, the new tutorials in the DX update are vastly better than the old ones, and once everything clicks you realize how d*** brilliant everything is.There are few things more exhilarating than flowing from platform to platform, effortlessly cleaning up all of the trash in your way. There are few things more satisfying than, after many restarts, nailing every jump and pressing every button at exactly the right time. There are few things more rewarding than racking up a 300+ combo and taking out all of the end-level enemies with the press of a button and seeing your janitor jump effortlessly around the screen, turning everything into a cloud of dust in slow motion, then falling to the ground with your newly-cleaned buddies, pumping your janitor's fist triumphantly. As said before, once everything clicks, you'll have a blast.TL;DR: Once you get the hang of this, you will experience one of the best platformers ever to one of the best soundtracks ever.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												This game is clearly way too hardcore for me. Levels are available in 3 basic tiers of difficulty, unlocked by sufficiently besting some levels of the previous tier, and then actually GETTING TO the level entrances in the hub area, which is oftentimes more sadistic than the levels themselves. I have gotten to exactly one of the third tier levels, and couldn't manage to get back to where I was afterwards.At a glance, it's a great concept, you speedrun levels while dealing with all the cleaning hotspots and keeping a combo going from start to finish if you want to S-rank it. In practice, unfortunately, I find myself wrestling with the controls twice as much as the level design. Entirely too often I'm kicking off of a wall when I was attempting to do a double-jump, clinging to the ceiling when I was trying to do a dash-jump, or dealing with the bizarre inertia that makes it impossible to just nudge yourself a half-inch in any direction when trying to set up for some precision platforming or just attempt that double-jump from a little farther away from the wall so I don't do a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wall jump by mistake again.Still recommended, but eh.It does come with a level editor at least.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Dustforce is a beautiful platformer with a very high skill cap. The premise of the game is to sweep each level while never letting your combo drop; which occurs when you have not swept up any dust after a set period of time. A flawless continuous sweep gives you a 'perfect' rating, which can unlock keys which you can use to enter more difficult levels. This is not necessary to enjoy the game, though, as many levels are available without unlocks and community made levels are plentiful and just as enjoyable. You can complete levels without perfecting them, though this gives you a worse rating and no key. Earning a perfect rating on difficult levels is really a challenge as the mechanics in Dustforce take hours, maybe even days of playtime to perfect. The game contains a leaderboard where you can watch replays of the best times to get a feel for how to perfect a level and different paths to take. Only a small handful of players have perfected every level, and I am not one of them. The challenge does not take away from the game, though, it is still a fantastic game with gorgeous visuals and a calming and beautiful soundtrack that I have listened to for nearly 3 years now. I highly suggest picking up Dustforce if you are a fan of difficult platformers and want a real challenge fit for a perfectionist.  Pros: -Beautiful art style and soundtrack, both go great together. -Difficult but rewarding controls and mechanics. -Tons of levels varying in difficulty. -Map editor and thousands of custom made levels from the community to keep you busy. -Leaderboard with a replay system which helps on more difficult levels. -4 different characters with their own slight differences.  Cons: -Some advanced mechanics are not taught in game and are to be learned via the replay system or fanmade tutorials on youtube. -Multiplayer mode is local only (I have never touched it). -Some of the most difficult levels are possibly too hard and require a lot of time to figure out and perfect (may not be a downside to some).Overall I'd I give it an 8/10. Also I suggest using a controller when playing, though this is personal preference.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Overview: An excellent precision platformer that puts emphasis on fine tuning each run and getting as close to impossibly perfect as possible.This game is designed exceptionally well. Everything feels intentional and like meticulous thought was put into it, this caries over into how you learn to play the game as well. In the Dustforce you progress in an spawling overworld by beating levels, gaining keys and subsequently unlocking harder levels. In reality you progress by obsessing over every fraction of a second you could have done better in order to get higher on the leaderboards. You can watch replays others playthroughs of the levels, which is a great resource for new players and works splendidly within game.You can play as 4 characters with slightly different traits, which really wont matter initially for the casual player but can make all the difference once you are acquainted with the game and aim to shoot hundreths of a second off your speed run.  The controls felt a bit loose (or more floaty) to me persoanlly, having just finished playing several other platformers, but it was easy to adjust to and may have just been me. You have an insane amount of mobility and the levels are designed to show this off, letting you fluidly slide around walls, ceiling floors, and lay down some beatdown on enemies when they show up. The music is mostly mellow and slow and almost seems contrary to the pressure of trying to perfect your run. It does a nice job at keep you calm after several trails on the same level. Local Multiplayer works well and is fun to play, and is a wonderful addition. The animations and style of the game look great, just look at dem screen shots above.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												It's really cool to see a platformer that uses action elements not to simply make the game have a fighting aspect, but to add a layer of complexity to platforming.  Every move that you can perform can be used in defense against enemies, but enemies are generally positioned in a way that allow the player to fight them while maintaining momentum through the levels.Difficulty for this game ramps up pretty quick, but the satisfaction of mastering an area or level in this game is super high.  The game is also quick to reset the player after messing up, so the penalty isn't very frustrating.To top it off, the game has an amazing soundtrack.  It complements the style of play very well.  I feel like the soothiness of the music has often made the time spent to master an area or level enjoyable.  I mean, this game gets pretty hard...it could be one of those "flip the table in frustration" games, but the environments and soundtrack are so relaxing that it's easy to convince yourself to keep trying.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												UPDATE: I've returned to the game to earn its Steam cards, trying the DX release. My impression this time around is more favorable: they seem to have eased the difficulty curve, with a wider variety of levels available at the outset. Maybe I'm just better at it this time around, but the combo system seems more forgiving, too. My overall rating is still "not recommended for most people," but it's definitely been improved since I played before.---I obtained Dustforce as part of a Humble Bundle, and it turned out to be one of the weakest entries of the set. Having enjoyed Super Meat Boy, I thought taking on another challenging speed/flow platformer would be good fun, but Dustforce didn't measure up.In premise, Dustforce seemed like a lot of fun. Ninja janitors! Fighting-game style uppercuts and kicks, used to navigate hazards and literally clean house! Some lovely sprite work and a fantastic soundtrack enticed me to give it a go.Unfortunately, Dustforce turns out to be one of those games where only the hardest of the hard core need apply, and no lesser player has any hope of wringing some entertainment from this sharp, unforgiving stone of a title. Unless you master the moves immediately (perhaps by some years' experience playing Street Fighter on the competitive scene?), you will fail constantly, progressing to the end of even the earliest levels only by determination and brute repetition. That in and of itself is not irredeemable--that's part and parcel of SMB's shtick, after all. However, the insult to injury is that speedrunning is mandatory. You cannot barely squeak out a level completion and advance in the game; you *must* achieve a ranking score in speed and thoroughness in order to earn keys to open additional levels. If you don't, well, enjoy replaying the first world a lot, because that's all you'll get to see.There is something to be said for defying the predominant game design pattern of "if you just play long enough, no matter your skill, you will win." And no doubt a truly elite button-pusher would revel in it here. But if you don't consider yourself such a chest-thumping master, you would do well to give this game a pass.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Dustforce DX Review This is my personal view on the game, and though you may disagree with some of the statements I make I stand with them nonetheless.Game was purchased in the Humble Indie Game bundle.Dustforce DX is platformer game like many other platformer games, with the primary objective of the game being to gain the fastest possible time accompanied by style and completion of a level as possible. It has a large player base, many levels to choose from, a level editor and plenty of UGC. Here's a list of pros and cons I've compiled which I felt summarise the game:ProsTidy graphics that are pleasing to the eye.OST's that can be enjoyable to listen to.A plethera of levels to choose from with varying levels of difficulty for the player.Solid gameplay mechanics that aid the game in differing from other generic platformers.Full gamepad support (Which I also highly recommend if you choose to buy this game).With those positives, you may wonder what made me not recommend this game. Well, here's the list of cons that detracted from the game, mostly personal preference:ConsSomewhat repetitive gameplay, as of many generic platformers. Gets exceedingly boring over extended periods of playtime, I had to resort to 15 minutes each session.Can feel extremely unrewarding at times, given the 'speedrun' feel to the game. Completing a section of a level you have been stuck on for a while does not mean success, but rather spending time trying to complete levels decreases your final score, which leads onto the next point.Can grind to a halt at certain parts of gameplay. By this, I mean some of the early levels can be gruelling and seem out of place, as early users as myself may find certain parts of a level too difficult to proceed on, meaning the rest of the level goes to waste as one part of the level cannot be completed. Ties in as hard parts of levels that take multiple tries to complete can be pointless in the end to complete.Speed problems. Not running speed, such as lag, but rather play speed. The game at times can feel sluggish, and over long stretches of rock can feel slow. The game can also lose momentum when you make a minor slip and parts of the level such as loops are impossible to make, ergo reducing your final score and sometimes making you backtrack.No threats. This one being more personal preference than the others, but every enemy I've encountered in the game so far (Around 20-25 levels in) has posed no threat, and at the most has only knocked me over for me to only recover again within a matter of a second. This makes levels seem somewhat bland, as the only enemy is the level itself.Again, somewhat more personal, the dash-jump mechanic is frustrating to carry out. The mechanic intends that you dash then jump on solid ground to jump a long distance without the need for a run-up, although for many times I have found in levels it is intended to be used I cannot carry out the dash-jump. This, for me, was mostly experienced on the Advanced Training level, where the game does not tell you HOW to dash-jump and the level is also seemingly harder than the previous two tutorials by far.For the points listed above, I cannot recommend this game. This game by no means is a bad game, as can provide some entertaining gameplay at points and is well made, but due to the way it plays, I would not recommend this game to a friend.Overall rating: 6/10TL;DR: Well made but frustrating to play at points and can be rather generic.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Nice stylized graphics, amazing OST. If you like time trial games, this game is for you. It has an actual legitimate leaderboard (with viewable replays), and I haven't seen any cheating on it.The game's system is very well conceived, staying simple enough for a novice to have fun, but has enough depth for an advanced player to distance themselves from the rest. There are 4 characters you can use, each one having slightly different attributes.This game can get really difficult if you're trying for SS rankings, or competing for top times in the leaderboards. If you're not into competing for times or going for 100% completion, then the game becomes considerably less difficult as you can utilize checkpoints in stages and retry from them as many times as you like.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Dustforce is a calming game. The game isn't labelled difficult for nothing, but the game is probably a very different tone than most you'd find under the category. Between the calming visuals and the serene soundtrack, I never really got that frustrated like I would in other difficult platformers: instead I got determined.That's part of the magic of Dustforce. It's one of those games that really lets you take the game at your own pace, do levels how you see fit. There's no plot or story which allows you to explore whichever unlocked door you want to first.It's a very easy game to get into, with challenge ramping and testing you throughout. The entire game is essentially a tutorial. Unlike similar describable games though, there is an endgame there.Enter the community. You can watch the top run that anyone has done in the game via the replay system. You can see how any of your friends tackled the level. You can see the guy who shaved a few frames off your time and see what he did differently. Anyone you meet who plays this game extensively is also incredibly friendly and just welcoming new faces to the game. It's got to have one of the best video game communities I've ever been bare to witness. So pick it up, try it out, see if it's your cup of tea. You might be surprised how fun cleaning can be, and how far you can take it.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Oh. My. God. How the hell have I missed playing this game up until now?! I can't actually find descriptive enough words to convey the utter brilliance of this game. The soundtrack is the best I've heard since the old time Legend of Zeldas and Final Fantasies. The fluidity and stylishness and light-heardedness of the movement and gameplay is a sight to behold. Personally, I feel like I get transported to another world when I play Dustforce.This game is a masterstroke, and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥is it satisfying.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Traditional platforming has never felt so graceful. If I had to sum up dustforce in one word it would be “Understated.” Everything from the stylized visual aesthetic, to the almost silhouette character sprites, the animations, enemies and even the level design all hold themselves with such dignity. The small flashes of flare that you get, when performing your special ability and the slow motion finishing move at the end of each level all give you a sense of “Yeah, I just did that, whatever.” As you calmly walk off from your amazing display of platforming prowess without even looking back.Mechanics wise, dustforce is a great example of giving the player a single minded goal, and the tools to get there. I forgot where I read it and i hope they don't mind the unattributed quote but it sums up so perfectly the mentality I draw from the game. “Dustforce is not content to let you be content with yourself.” Again apologies for probably butchering the original quote but it is so true.Dustforce has a tiered level structure where you unlock keys to higher tiered levels by completing previous ones to a certain proficiency. While simply completing the level from start to finish may be enough at the start to work towards a few keys and level, you will eventually need to break past your preconceived limits. This system of partial completion still progressing the player is great for giving the player control over their own difficulty curve and doesn’t fall into the pit of so many other challenging platformers where you get stuck on a single level and cannot progress.Another thing it does great is support the players journey of self improvement without being overbearing. After completing any particular level you are given access to the high scores from the community. But where other games may stop there dustforce then records the exact run of that player so that you can view it whenever you want in its entirety. I cannot tell you the amount of times I was stuck on certain levels but then was able to completely change my approach after seeing a “pro” do it in front of my eyes.But no game is perfect and Dustforce is no exception. The physics and movement in the game is very momentum based. If you are unable to continue your exact series of boosts and ramp launches you will find your experience rather jerky. When it works it makes speed runs a visually awe inspiring art, but when it doesn't you find yourself spamming jumps off walls at odd angle into spike pits or off cliffs.I would recommend this game to anyone that loves tried and tested platforming mechanics with a stylish coat of paint and some really nice quality of life features. And to anyone that loves the feeling of becoming one with your controller, eye's glazed, as you become one with the game and skirt even the most precarious platform dungeons with grace and ease.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												Dustforce is one of the best games I've played in the 2D platformer category.The controls are very tight and well made, having the possibility to do everything from the beginning - your skills progression solely depend on your increasing understanding and ability to control your janitor. If you're into a whole lot of challenge, this game can provide it. (and if you're easily frustrated by absurd difficulty, which exists in the later part of this game - consider avoiding the game).The graphics are beautiful, atmospheric and give each level-set a defined feel and flow.The soundtrack is a bit too relaxed sometimes for my taste, but overall really great.I am close to - but have not finished the game yet and played mostly the provided levels, but I know there are plenty of rich community levels, besides the base content.So far it has been a great challenge a lot of fun - I highly recommend this game. (and consequently also look forward to Hitbox Team's Spire).

												Dustforce is a wonderful little platformer. It's extremely hard, at least when you get to the later levels, but the earlier ones are perfectly designed and super fun, and pushing against your records for time is enjoyable by itself, without necessarily beating all the levels. I think the best part about the game is how tightly designed it is, in terms of the controls and the interface, and the leaderboard system. This could have very easily been an underwhelming game if it was just a series of levels with nothing to encourage you to beat your score or watch other people's runs. If the idea of a time trial 2d platformer sounds appealing to you, you should really get this game.

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												When I first found out about the crew of Dustforce and their follies in amateur game development, I became very anxious to play this game and to support them. However, playing the actual game has shown me that good intentions do not necessarily translate into a full experience.I think that Dustforce's biggest problem is how it defines 'skill' and 'difficulty'. Dustforce has very little in the way of rewarding a player, only giving out keys which are used to unlock a handful of harder levels. When most of the game's content is unlocked from the start, the player's only remaining motivation is the scoreboard. When one takes a cursory glance at said scoreboard, one notices very long strings of players who complete the level in virtually the same amount of time, give or take a fraction of a second. Not only that, but the requirement of sweeping all dust in a level for a perfect score causes every level, regardless of size, to develop a 'one true path' that sacrifices exploration and player experience for the sake of a higher score. This makes the game extremely tedious to play, boiling itself down to memorization of a level and restarting the level at the slightest mishap.I'm aware that the game is designed with the speedrunning community in mind, but one reason as to why speedrunning is so highly valued in those circles is the fact that speedrunners interpret a game in a different manner than the developers, and play it at a much faster speed than intended, entertaining others who are only familiar with a more down-to-earth means of beating the game. Meanwhile, Dustforce's design mentality is rigidly geared towards beating the levels as fast as possible, causing the practice of speedrunning to be rendered pedestrian, and therefore moot. Aside from the core gameplay, which is admittedly quite interesting despite its flawed implementation, there is honestly not much else to say about Dustforce. I did like how the game's various sprites were traditionally animated, but the artstyle itself is so minimalistic that the subtlties and quirks that normally come with such techniques are lost. The music on its own is good, but not exciting or emotional, causing it to simply blend into the background, when music should enhance the player's experience by being memorable or unique.When looking at Hitbox Team's upcoming Spire, I'm glad to see that the team is taking more consideration to the skill of the individual and motivating the individual to get better in order to progress further. Hopefully, it'll make for a more rewarding and engaging experience than Dustforce, which, in my opinion, feels like more of a chore than actual dusting.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												TLDR; Supermeatboy ftw.I have played a few more hours than shows here.  Not that many more though... I really love the idea of this game. I wish I would like it. In the end it comes down mostly to control responsiveness.Even the simplest jumps feel hard to accomplish, movement feels jerky and if you miss a wallrun edge by a pixel the outcome is completely different and unexpected. I guess you can get used to it and "get good", but in this day and age there are so many games that do this right and feel natural, responsive and tight from the get-go while still having a crazy high skill ceiling. Supermeatboy: I'm looking at you and blowing a kiss.Because of this little mistakes completely ruin your runs. Maybe it's by design, but I don't like it. I feel little mistakes should screw you a little and big mistakes screw you a lot. Controller support exists (I play using an xbox360 controller), but it still feels funny. Some commands register on soft presses while others require full presses...Ah and the game's pacing: While it demands big apm spikes there's more focus on precision and routing than hectic speed. So it feels weird: sluggish, complex and puzzling, kinda like that weirdly chosen soothing new age soundtrack. Few games can make me yawn and get frustrated at the same time.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dustforce is an interesting little side-scrolling platformer where you play as one of four (approximately equal) characters to literally clean up various levels. To me, this game is a lot like Sonic the Hedgehog with smaller levels and more specific goals. All you really need to do is get to the end of the level and clean the 'boss'. However, to progress you need to meet certain goals: % of the level cleaned and point value, which you get by maintaining a combo for as long as possible.The graphics are interesting but nothing terribly special- I think it could be best described as artistically minimal. The audio is there, but neither good nor bad. The story... well, a game like this doesn't really need much of a story.Mechanically the game is pretty solid. There are times when it feels like the controls aren't as tight as they could be, and the objective-based advancement means you find yourself doing many iterations of the same frustrating levels. The game does have controller support, but you'll have to do a lot of rigging to make it work right.Its an interesting challenge game, but lacks a certain something. It doesn't make it bad, just... not something I play at for long periods. This indie title is still worth playing though, so consider picking it up if it happens to be on sale.If you found this review useful, please have a look at my other reviews.[/url]

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												I really tried to like this game. But after about four hours of play time and not one minute of fun I gave up on this game. Here are the reasons for this.Instead of moving smoothly you kind of "trigger" fixed movement schemes (e.g. pressing right ones makes about two or three steps to the right). Because of this your input does not always have an effect on the movement. This means that precise timing and reactions are less important than pure mezmorizing and in the worst cases playing felt more like a long boring quick time event. Personally I can't stand QTE's.In order to progress you have to collect every single piece (!) of dust in a level. To me this feels like a goal that should clearly be optional. Suppose some Mario game that says: "Oh, you didn't collect every coin in the level. Go back to the beginning." Another problem is that this completely breaks the flow of the gameplay. So instead of going for a quick smooth run you turn around and do backtracking to collect the last pieces of dust. In most levels this acutally seems to be what the level-designers intended.In order to progress to must also make sure that your combo-chain does not break, whichs happen if you didn't collect dust for some time. I think this is supposed to force the player to make a "smooth" run, but it doesn't. The problem is that usually there is dust in so many places that messing it up first try and clumsily turning around is a valid option. I really don't understand what the developers were going for with this. Why is going through a level fast not rewarded in a game that (I think) is basically designed to be a speedrunner-heaven. Also it should be way better indicated when the combo-chain breaks.Another minor complaint is that the tutorial just does not give you enough information to play the game. You have to figure out  the details of the gameplay-mechanics yourself, it is never explained what the finesse-ranking is based on and neither does the game explain that you actually need double-S ranking in order to unlock all levels (which is by the way stupid as (insert insulting word here) anyway).

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												There is nothing bad to say about this game. Nothing.The soundtrack is a unique, atmospheric montage of skillfully crafted musical sounds. The gameplay is flawless and exciting, and can be quite the challenge to those who think they've seen all the game has to offer! With an intricate overworld, gorgeous scenery, and riveting gameplay, this is a must-have game for anyone who enjoys platformers or video games in general.There are hidden spots in every level where you can sit and enjoy the scenery for as long as you like, all while relaxing to the fabulous soundtrack. There are hidden secrets which add to the game's depth as you struggle to find at least one in every level of every one of the four worlds. For an indie game, it does everything right.The controls are responsive and they will not miss an input unless you put in a dash while you're in the air (as that won't happen on any game anyways). Each level is better than the last, and there's a Tome of Levels for you to visit your favorites if you choose not to run through the overworld to get to it. Please play it with a controller, as keyboard takes getting used to.All in all, this game is wonderful. For me personally not worth 10 bucks or whatever it goes for, but you can get it every few months in a bundle for a dollar with some other games, so there's always that.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												It's a shame. I really enjoyed watching speedruns of Dustforce. I had high hopes that I'd be able to do the same stunts that several of the top players displayed in various playthroughs. Unfortunately, this game has ultimately taught me the difference between watching videos of Dustforce and physically playing Dustforce.+Pros: Beautiful music (very relaxing!) and art. Fun to watch. Competitive for the speedrunning community. High replay value*-Cons: Stiff controls, hard to master even after brushing and practicing the tutorial several times, confusing hub world, definitely not worth the $9.99 price tag.Summary:While the gameplay looks impressive, the controls are extremely stiff and difficult to master (actions like jumping are delayed once the button is pressed, not immediate). After the tutorial, you'll have to perform the actions you just learned to enter a door that leads to a hub world; this took me a bunch of tries (I just wanted to play the game already!). There's no sense of direction in this hub world; I found myself entering harder levels earlier just because I was wandering around aimlessly. Without a sense of direction (especially on a first playthrough), casual players will find the difficulty going all over the place rather than easier--->harder levels. With an insanely steep learning curve and a non-linear flow of gameplay, I don't feel enticed to explore this game further after 5+ hours of trying to work with the game's mechanics.*Because Dustforce drives players to complete levels as fast as possible, much of the core gameplay revolves around beating your personal best time. I've had some experience with speedrunning games and personally, I can't find enjoyment from trying to beat my times if I cannot enjoy the controls and core mechanics of the game first. Dustforce isn't something I can recommend to anyone unless they find entertainment in learning every inch of mechanic possible in this game through countless repitition and muscle memory

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I don't like Dustforce, and I can't really put my finger on why, though I have my suspicions. Let's start with all the things this game does right, though:-Cool theme/graphical style-Fun characters (all functionally identical, but visually distinct)-Pleasant musicSo what's wrong with Dustforce? It's hard to put into words, as the vocabulary for platform video game reviewing is still in its infancy and words like "floaty", "mushy", "heavy", "satisfying" and so on are all very subjective. If I was forced to put it into words, I'd say that your character is too heavy, yet doesn't have enough inertia - it takes a while to get up to speed, and it's very easy to lose that momentum with the way that levels are designed. It's fairly fluid when you play perfectly, but it falls apart in the hands of an inexpert player. What else?The overworld is directionless and confusing. There are no (threatening) enemies, so this is purely platforming for the sake of platforming. Rarely are you directly challenged - the game is clearly designed for speedrun enthusiasts.Here in the modern era of gaming, you have tons of options if you're looking to run and jump on some platforms. If I were you, I'd be cautious about this one. Check out Super Meat Boy instead.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												"Cleaning up dust wasn't as much fun as I thought it'd be." 5/10I never thought I'd see the day where I wanted to play a game that revolved around cleaning up dust particles, but nevertheless, here we are. They say never judge a book by it's cover. Well, never judge a video game by it's screenshots. For this game appeared to have it all, but managed to fall short. Let me start out by saying that I loved the art style though, along with the soundtrack. In fact, the soundtrack is probably the best part about 'Dustforce' and is exactly what you want in a platformer. As for the controls, they are nowhere near as bad as some of the people on here make them out to be, and personally I found them to be quite good. The only thing that stinks is how they make you assign the controller buttons yourself, as opposed to just having them preset for you. I wouldn't even dream of using a keyboard to play this game. As you may already know, this game was made with speedrunning in mind. Speedrunning is something I enjoy watching, but not performing, and had I known that beforehand, I would have skipped this game entirely. I mean, who makes a game specifically tailored for speedruns? Getting to the end of a level as quickly as possible? Where's the fun in that? No, I like to take my time, look around, really take in my surroundings. And besides, isn't the whole fun in speedrunning, coming up with the fastest method on your own? It just doesn't make much sense if you ask me. Aside from that, there's pretty much nothing else to do in this game but run from door to door playing level after level for the best time. No bosses, no enemies, just jumping from one platform to another, climbing wall after wall, sweeping up that dirty dust. There just doesn't feel like much of a reason to continue playing 'Dustforce' after an hour or two, unless you care about posting the highest scores for all to see. Which is basically where 99% of the incentive to continue playing comes from; the highest possible score. On the other hand, I can definitely see how people enjoy playing this game. Like I said, the soundtrack is great, the art style although simplistic, works quite well, and the controls are pretty good.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												If you're a fan of ninja-styled mechanics in platformers, I would say to ignore this title. There isn't any real way to maintain speed, the keyboard assignment is terrible, and the jumps and movement in the game seem to be too consistent. That's right. TOO consistent.Think games like Mario Bros. or N+, where you can just tap a jump or movement key and only move a small amount.This game doesn't follow that at all, at least on keyboard controls.While playing, I found a set of ledges with a gap just big enough for the character to fall between, but for some reason, the game will still "jump" you from one platform to the next even while trying to walk and fall between them. Again, there is no small movement in the game. In trying to make a time-based fluid movement, they have done away with sensitivity, making technical parts of levels more difficult than they should be.

In Dustforce you play as a very acrobatic ninja like janitor going from level to level freeing animals from clouds of leaves and clean up everything along the way.The lack of native controller support is rough but can be rebound which makes the gameplay feel more natural.  The concept and movement animations for this game are great with strong level design.However much of that is marred by finicky rules for how movement actions are allowed.  The uncertainty of when you have a double jump or not makes the platforming more frustrating than fun.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Was excited to try the game, and then thurougly let down. It is an interesting (albeit kinda boring) idea you just sweep everything up. There is not story whatsoever (meh). Music seems fine. Then the problems happen. The game requires all these tricky movements and long fluid combos, but the controls and mechanics and super finnicky, inconsistent and dont work half the time. Sometimes I will be able to jump after a wall-run, while other times I won't. Sometimes I will only get a single jump and sometimes I will get a double jump. It seems stupid to me you can't double jump, wall run, and double jump again. The wall running and ceiling running is the worst crime. Sometimes I will be able to run up a wall, and other times I will hold against it and my gun will just run a tiny bit or won't even start a wallrun. One part to get to a new area my guy runs up and then on the ceiling, then just stops for no reason. I try to jump to the next area and hold over because the ledge is right there, but he just won't react to any buttons and falls down. This makes no sense. Sometimes you can run on the ceiling and then around on to the wall, and other times it won't. It just seems the people want to game to be more fluid, but the controls aren't consistent enough. The movements are also floaty and you will try to jump next to something and overshoot it or you will try to double jump next to a wall and instead it will make you run up it. Same goes with hitting, which you can hit up, but at and angle. Countless times I would be next to a guy and hit, only to go through him because I was TOO CLOSE and I wasn't at the perfect spot where the end of my broom ended exactly on his body, but thats like saying you can't hit someone with a sword because they aren't at the tip......I still hit him with the rest of my broom it should count. Very questionable hit recognition. Then there is the level design. Instead of making the levels easy to get to, like the level book, you can only look at them and replay unlocked ones, which seems dumb, because I'd rather be able to play the ones I haven't yet. Instead there is this open map with tons of different platforms and branching paths, and I am supposed to find every unlockable level by exploring....what this does is make me wonder if I have missed levels, and the only way to find out is to backtrack and try to make sense of things. Why not have the levels you created that you want people to play accessible, not in a convoluted area where people can easily miss them. Then there are levels and are like impossible to get it. I went through and played all the levels that seemed accessible and apparent how to get to them, and I know there are more but have no clue how to get to them, and then other parts I am wondering if there are other ways to get to. This shouldn't be that way this early to leave this many levels on the table like that. I don't understand why they would add the monotony of walking from door to door and retracing steps and trying to figure out how to get to this impossible looking spot, just to play the levels of a platformer, it seems counterintuitive to me. Why waste time with boring things when we just want to get to the good parts.Also they say controller support, but it doesn't automatically detect it, and you have to manually reset all of the buttons, and even then you can't use just the controller, because you can't program start to pause or use the controller on the menus very well....for a platformer thats a mistake by them.And i know there are people on here that are tryhards that are like "I don't have any of these problems" and "you're just bad" but the fact is I'm not, I've played tons of platformers. I recently played a game called freedom fall that had tight controls and I had no problems with. The people that I mentioned above that will say those things, put like 70 hours into the game, and it shouldn't take that long to try and get consistency out of movement controls, they shouldn't take that much repetition and effort to figure them out, they should be obvious. I have played other games that do wall-running, air juggling, and sliding, better than this. Also there is the keys and the scores. I mentioned in my "AAAAA for awesome" that scores are cool for the tryhards like the ones that want to SS everything and spend 20 hours on 20 levels, but you shouldn't force that. I shouldn't have to get certain preset scores to unlock more levels by getting keys based on my score. Just let me play the levels you created. I do like how they included level editor, multiplayer, and the community maps, although those are just a lot of dumb ones with all spikes created by tryhards that want you to be perfect with moves and have spent 60 hours like them, so I wasn't impressed with some of the creations. 4.5/10.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												This game is just terrible when it comes to learning how to play it. If you can learn to play it, then I imagine ti would be an awesome game.The learning curve. You look at hard platform games like super meat boy or electronic super joy, these are hard games. But the learning curves are pretty good.  But this game just lacks that entirely.Before the "DX" update, it was impossible to "get into the game" without already having knowledge of it. In the new DX update, things are easier, but they are still not perfect. I mean, for goodness sake, in order to even reach the 3rd tutorial, you seem to require the knowldge that is taught to you in that 3rd tutorial. (i.e. dash-jumping) It is very badly designed.Having not been able to play them, I can't speak for the design of the later levels.The control scheme for this game is impossible to use. In order to set it up to use a controller, you need to set up each button manually. And if you do set it up with a controller, it is impossible to switch back to keyboard without again manually resetting each button, via your controller. And god help you if you can't connect your controller again to do this. Also, I can't seem to figure out why the menu can't be opened by the controller. It can only be opened by pressing Esc on the keyboard.Now, as for the music and art in this game, it looks really good.  Kudos to the dev team for that. The music is very calming (which is helpful in alleviating frustration), and the art style is simplistic, but avoids feeling "flat".To summarize, I really think this game is lacking a lot in the way of easing new players in. It is just impossible to learn how to play it. Even with help from snipppets of conversations in the forums, it just feels like it's missing something. That, or I am the one missing something here.[Incidentally, if anyone knows what it is that i'm missing, please tell me, because I really want to be able to play this game].

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24
												Sorry, I really wanted to like this and came back to it several times but...It feels good when you get in the flow, but that's too hard to do. I wish steam had a neutral recommendation because I'd give it to this game, but it doesn't so I have to give it a negative one.I know people are going to write some dumb "lol ur just bad git gud lolol" comments. The problem is I played for 2 hours and I couldn't figure out what I was doing wrong. The double-jumping (or triple jumping with the purple character) seemed to have some nebulous rules governing it that I simply couldn't explain. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't. I played around with it trying to figure out how it works, and it seemed random to me. Apparently it just has no leniency when jumping off of ledges and my initial jumps were counting as air jumps. This is just weird design, especially for a game that emphasizes speed. I can't think of another platformer that's so strict. That leniency is necessary because characters take up a 2D space on screen. You can't just pick any point beneath Mario and say "yeah if he hangs that far off the platform he falls" like these devs seem to have done. I've played hard games before, including From's 3D Dot Game Heroes which was downright cruel and way harder than their Souls series', but I didn't have to google the issue and forget 20 years of game experience to "git gud." If I have to google your core game mechanics, you did a poor jobThe level progression is also ridiculous and keeps you from playing all of the bronze levels if you don't *perfect* all of the basic ones, so you're kinda screwed if you can't do that

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												I've really tried to like this game over the past 5 or so years I've owned it. I love the concept, but I really can't say I enjoy the 'feel' of the game. It has some weird momentum-based physics that give it a sort of 'floaty' feel to it. A lot of people will call this a precision-based platformer. I would call it pretentious. The devs did well to implement a series of tutorials, as they thought the game was too hard for many. However, there are still a ton of hidden mechanics that aren't explicitly taught to the player, so it's often confusing once you've completed a certain number of levels on where to head next. Until you know what's possible in the context of the game, it's really off-putting. I shouldn't have to go to forums and YouTube to determine that there are many completely obtuse things hidden in the game's mechanics in order to proceed. Additionally, there are numerous bugs this game has, such as the game deciding it will automatically use up your double jump if you are too close to an edge. Mr Peck on YouTube has these documented, if you want some evidence of them. Tons of optimization problems, such as crashing if you alt+tab out of the window and simply setting up a controller is a nightmare if you want to switch between keyboard and gamepad; buttons across both is frustrating. They should have just used a 'set all buttons' command and let the player sequentially determine the mappings.If I were looking for a game in this genre, it'd be Wings of Vi over this - feels way better.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												I actually found myself rather excited to see Steam Trading Cards brought to Dustforce so late into it’s life. They gave me a good reason to go sink a few more hours into game when I don’t know that I would have played it again out of my own interest. I was absolutely dreadful at the game but the art, music, world and just the overall premise of the title really charmed me. I personally would have never bought Dustforce had it not been part of a bundle, but everything about the game was well done and lovingly put together and it really showed.Sadly, something has changed. I booted the game back up to sweep some leaves and collect some cards and all of the mechanics are just broken. The controls are floaty and imprecise, the character seems to have a bizarre response time and beyond the fact that I openly admit I was dreadful at the game upon it’s release, whatever updates that have been put in place since then have made it completely unplayable. It’s truly a shame, but I can no longer say I recommend Dustforce.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Dustforce is a relentlessly unforgiving platformer, even moreso than Super Meat Boy. In most platformers, there are usually a few different ways to approach problems. In Dustforce, however, you are forced into a single kind of "perfect run" to progress normally through the game. You can complete stages without these perfect runs, but by doing so, you lock yourself out of so many stages. Perfection is demanded of you in this game.I'm the kind of person that really enjoys a challenge, but the level of timing, reaction, knowledge, and control demanded of the player is so insane that I made it about 75% of the game before finally stopping to retain my sanity. When you can pull off what it demanded, it is an amazing feeling. But sometimes the game feels incredibly inconsistent, and I know that's only because the timing on everything in this game is on a hair-trigger. I find it really hard to recommend this game except to anyone who is masochistic about challenging games. I did actually really enjoy it myself (I am one of those people), but I also know this is not the kind of game that almost anyone else would be able to enjoy the way I was able to.3 out of 5 foxes.

number of helpful: 7 of 25 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												For its length and number of different worlds and characters available, Dustforce offers almost no variety at all. Worlds are only thematic variations, repeating the same kind of level structure over and over with no unique mechanics between them, while the characters themselves all play pretty much the same, with some minor tweaks from one character to another (with some of the more subtle changes not even being hinted in-game).If that wasn't enough, the game demands "perfect" double-S scores for players to be able to make standard progress. Scores that in any other game would exist only as a side challenge to those who truly want to spend their times mastering it. Here, you'll have to clear every single stage flawlessly if you ever hope to see those final levels, and there are MANY stages to be mastered — enough to make one feel like the game overstayed its welcome after only a few hours.Bottom line is: Dustforce gets old. Fast. It offers almost no variety in its gameplay and the absurd requirement to progress through stages is a cheap way of stepping up the difficulty, which only helps to add to the incessant repetition the player will experience. I cleared one world + a bunch of other stages and saw no point in continuing. It offers no reason to go on beyond getting a good performance on stages, so you can move on to more stages and repeat the process in the exact same way, everytime. I felt like I had already seen all the game had to offer, and that more arrangements of the same stage elements weren't really worth stressing over.It's a shame, really. Dustforce has tight controls and a unique core theme and aesthetics (though it keeps the same kind of mild/serene atmosphere all the way through. I got bored of it after a while). If it just presented new mechanics for each world and/or character and reduced the overly-demanding difficulty a tad (a double-A ranking requirement to get keys for further stages would be a huge improvement) this review could have been a "Yes" instead. The way it is, though, I'd only recommend this game to the most time-attack obsessed players with plenty of time to burn and that wouldn't care much for a more varied and rich experience.For everyone else looking for an interesting platforming experience, you're better off looking elsewhere.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												This is an absolute gem! If you are the type that loves a challenge and enjoys platforming, this is a must-try game. This game is deceptively simple as there are a few sets of moves and mechanics that govern its world. But, as each level goes on, you start to use them in ways that did not seem apparent to keep your momentum.Some of the great features this game has are the quick-reset. Guys, you are likely to mess up, fail, over and over and OVER again with this. So have a quick-button reset is a great feature, especially for speed runner enthusiasts. This game is built to be played to ways, 1) complete the whole level with 100% finesse at the fastest time possible, or 2) reach the end of the level as quick as you can. Either way, there is something satisfying to both aims, and much more gratification once you see your name inch higher into the ranking boards.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												One of the most compelling and challenging speedrunners that I've ever played, Dustforce is not a platformer for the casual player. Even though you think you won't go back and try to perfect every level, the game will call out to your inner OCD, not just in the gamer's sense, but also the cleaner's sense.In fact, this is probably not the hypochondriac's kind of game. Unless, of course, you're into that sort of thing.

Posted: February 13, 2012
												My first instinct is to call Dustforce the relaxed cousin of Super Meat Boy, but that's not quite right.  Sure, it's got wall-jumping, air-dashing heroes, but the gameplay is more akin to racing around a track than trying to pass through a hostile environment.  The elegent controls let you achieve a zen that lets you almost float through a level without stopping, all while looking impressive with a top-notch simplistic art style and catchy music.It's not a terribly difficult game, but pulling a double-S rank on a stage is still incredibly rewarding.  Comparing scores with friends and passing the controller is a lot of fun, but the actual multiplayer feels tacked on.  There's no co-op as promised, only a survival deathmatch and king-of-the-hill style play.  For this game, though, multiplayer really isn't necessary to make the title worth the purchase.All in all, it's a hip platformer that's a lot of fun without risking a broken controller.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												A game for competitive, experienced players, Dust Force combines the fast-paced action you'll get from a fighting game and combines it with a cinematic parkour experience that's perfect for speed-runners. With four characters to choose from, you'll be slowly migrating between these characters and learning how they work. Your first gold level you've unlocked will seem like a walk in the park once you're in the later stages. There's a ton of levels, a slew of hidden mechanics, easter eggs in seemingly all stages, a local multiplayer mode for up to four players, a fantastic level editor, and an experienced community filled with tons of downloadable maps.All in all, if you like fast-paced platformers involving wall-running, timers, an unforgettable soundtrack, and hidden mechanics, this is your game. Thumbs up.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												If you have a completionist personality and get addicted to things because of it, you will most certainly get your money's worth out of this game. There's no guarantee you'll enjoy it all, but at least you'll get your money's worth.Dustforce combines speedrunning and combat to create an intense "race against the clock" battle in each level. The basis is to clean up as much of the level as you can in order to advance on to the next levels, each one being more difficult than the last.This game prides itself in its level design, and therefore also in its aesthetics. Its levels, characters, enemies, and even movements are visually pleasing, which helps when you play the game for hours on end in order to beat it. The sound design is similar, having a bit of the "fresh" element to it in order to keep you from getting sick of playing. Secrets are also scattered around levels, awaiting the player's arrival to reveal themselves--and then unfortunately yield no product. All of this wrapped in a thoroughly-vetted world makes for an overall good game, worth the buy.However, if you're not a completionist, I would approach this purchase with caution. As I said before, because this is an extensive game with many, many levels, you'll get your money's worth, but only if you're able to play them. You can only advance on to the more difficult levels in this game if you beat the previous level well enough, and eventually this stops your progress entirely until you return to fully complete the previous levels (which can be extremely difficult later on). Most importantly, if you're not enjoying it, then you'll more than likely quit and never return. So, again, think well before buying it if you don't want to be completionist and then waste your money.(Also, there is a multiplayer function to this game, but I don't have friends who own the game so I can't say whether that's worth a try or not. Given the game's speed-combat combination, I imagine it would be fun but can't say for certain!)

Posted: September 22, 2014
												Here's a little indie title that I absolutely LOVED to death. It's a free running, precision platformer (and mind you, I'm not the BIGGEST precision platformer) but I fell in love with the art direction of this game. The controls are tight and the levels are solidly routed to be as free flowing as possible depending on the character you choose (though some characters are better suited to specific levels than others fyi).It's a simple game with simple goals and you can start and stop any time. I personally aced every level until I reached the bonus level whereupon I gave up because they required godlike reflexes that I simply do not possess but I had fun nonetheless. Give this a try if you have some cash and time to spare, even if it's only 5-10 minutes at a time.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												This is one of the best indie games I have played. The game concept is so simple yet it is executed so well. The artwork and animation is amazing and fluid. It's one of those games that if you're really good at playing it looks so cool. Soundtrack is one of the best I heard of, I have a hard time getting these catchy tunes out of my head. Controls are nice and smooth as well; however, I recommend you get a gamepad, if you don't hate yourself (default controls on pc are pretty bad, but that can be changed). The only bad side really is the difficulty. I have beaten every level except Yotta Difficult(really game designers? I like a good challenge but jeez), and I have taken so much time. I'd be lying if I said I didn't rage when I almost got an SS rank on a hard level after 3 hours. So yes, there is a high-learning curve to this game, but you get exponentially better as you play more so don't let that discourage you. There is always a challenge in this game, which would appeal to any hardcore gamer. Still, this game deserves 10/10.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												Honestly, this is one of the most awesome platformers I've ever played.It's also the most difficult platformer I've ever played.Visuals are amazing, soundtrack kicks♥♥♥♥♥ presentation is very slick. But the real reason this game shines is because of the platforming.The way that you move about the environment is, for lack of a better term, beautiful. You can double-jump, dash around, slide down slopes, and run up walls and across ceilings. All of the levels test your ability to string together and combine these skills as you run through.At first, just trying to complete some levels is a daunting task. Many of the harder stages require some pixel- or frame-perfect actions to maneuver through tight corridors full of spikes. I never became frustrated with dying in this game because I always felt like a death or a combo break was my fault and not the game's. But once I cleared a difficult stage with a double-S rating, it was an awesome feeling every time. Getting through a level on a perfect run looks and feels like an intricate dance, and it provides a level of satisfaction that surpasses any other platformer I've played.All that said, I don't think I will ever beat this game. The late-game stages are just insanely brutal, and I'm not sure that I can spend the numerous hours needed to optimize my movement through just one of them to get a double-S. But I'm quite okay with that, and I'll definitely try anyway.

Posted: October 8, 2012
												When I first seen this game, I wanted it and added it to my wishlist.  Just looked like a fun, hop around, kill, and completion game.However I did not enjoy it nearly to the point I thought I would.  This is actually more like Super Meat Boy with brooms.  Only not as fun, not as funny, and controls not nearly as tight.Not a bad game, but I felt myself being bugged by the controls and there is no real combat: only appears that way.The basic idea is that you pick a zone, then pick an area within the zone to clean dust/leaves/goo by jumping and sliding along the walls.  At the end you kill a few monsters who cannot hurt you and the level is over.  You get points to unlock keys to open more areas to do the same thing.Each of the four janitors plays a little different, but all of them feel a bit awkward or delayed.  More of a muscle memory on some of the levels and not precise contrtols.  Just not as good as what I wanted.

Posted: January 25, 2013
												Looking for an ultra-hard, stylish, hi-score oriented platformer? Oh look here's one right now!At first I thought it would be like a Super Meat Boy, and in a way it is, but... if you think any of your hard-learned Meat Boy prowess will help you here, you are gravely mistaken and you are going to need to waterproof your gamepad and/or keyboard because there will be a lot of tears.Meat Boy's approach to wall jumping mechanics was very simple, and the challenges were largely about precision.Dustforce take a much more strict approach. Rather than simply megaman your way up a wall, you can run up it- for a short distance. Then you'll either need a facing wall, or to spend your precious precious second jump, the one you can't get back without landing on solid ground or killing an enemy in midair. You can also run along slopes and ceilings, air dash, and a number of other fancy tricks that look super cool but all add complexity.The challenges here are not only about precision, but also working out how long you can save that air jump, which direction to hold (or not hold) when you make contact with the wall, or how to get that extra bit of dust up on the ceiling.Unfortunately, the experience is hurt a little by slightly picky controls and the rather annoying way momentum is handled when you've wall-run up to the edge of a platform (or anything treated as one, whether it has spikes on it or not).All in all, I enjoy it, even though the gold-key levels make me furious.

Posted: January 27, 2013
												I bought this because the sountrack + game bundle on steam was only $1 more than the soundtrack off the artist's Bandcamp page.  I already liked the music so I'd figure for a dollar more I'd try the game.Arguably, this is not my game.  I dont find enjoyment in time trials, or in repeat-til-learned drilling gameplay.  I just don't appreciate it.  So that said, it is hard for me to evaluate this game because that's what the game is.  The music is great, I love that.  It helps add a lot to the aesthetic and the game is stylish and captures a feeling of 'coolness' nicely.  I can't comment on the controls because I have no frame of reference.  The game is demanding so naturally I felt flustered and struggled to accomplish the desired action.  As I said, its not my kind of game.So I guess I'd say pick this up if you like games like Super Meat Boy or N+?  It has a local multiplayer mode somewhat lightly comparable to SSB without items or health meters, but its not online so application for alternative play is limited.
