Posted: November 14, 2015
												What a great addition to the platformer genre. Dustforce is an indie action platformer from Hitbox Team. Let’s get rocking.The GoodI love platformers and Dustforce made me remember why I love platformers. Everything about this game is well done and polished until it shines.First thing first, you’ll be hard pressed to find another game with as good a soundtrack as the one that accompanies Dustforce. It is pure, relaxing majesty and nothing could possibly fit this game better in terms of music. It makes you feel good while you play.The art is phenomenal. Character designs are simple and beautiful, enemies are original, and the environments themselves will provide you with a good eyeful as well.The controls are smooth and fluid. You can easily transition from floors to ceilings in a matter of seconds, all the while cleaning the living hell out of dust ridden creatures and persons. Dustforce is, essentially, 2D parkour and I love it.There are a huge amount of levels for you to play through with four different characters, all of whom have their own play style. Not only does the core game have over 100 levels, but there are a heaping amount of user created levels that you can play through as well. The fun doesn’t have to end with this one, ever.The BadNothing. Nothing at all my friends.The MehSee the above category, please.Verdict: YeaDustforce is a lighthearted, refreshing platformer that serious and casual gamers alike can enjoy at their leisure. If you’re looking for something new to play, look no further. As always, thanks for reading.

Posted: November 5, 2013
												Dustforce is a bipolar experience. Sublimely calming throughout with an insurmountable skill level.  The things that make Dustforce one of my favorite games are things that seem obvious a few years out now, but they're worth saying for someone who hasn't experienced it.  The soundtrack, by Lifeformed, is transcendent.  It has trappings of dubstep and chillwave but so much attention gets paid to cohesive textures and melodies that no song becomes just a genre-piece.  You will listen to this soundtrack outside of the game, and I've played this sountrack at work, heard it used on NPR, and my friends who have never played Dustforce have heard it.  The visuals are  better than they need to be.  They could have been retro 8 or 16-bit, which would make sense with the pizel perfect gameplay, or they could have been bulky flash graphics, or boring minimalist nonsense, or they could have been cheesy 3D graphics, or anything else that you'll find by flipping through the other platformers on Steam.  Instead, what they are are a beautiful flat colors, equally evoking 16-bit clarity and Gamecueb-era cel shading.  The game could have been a linear experience, lacking a hub-world and natural progression like Super Mario 3D Land.  But what we get is a branching, growing, player-guided progression through multiple worlds in a hubworld that is more of a sequel to Peach's Castle from Super Mario 64 than anything.  In order to access certain levels, you have to develop the skills necessary to play through those levels by traversing increasingly difficult areas of the hub world, accomplishing not only training a new player but evoking exploration and the unique atmospheres of each world.  It's these reasons that make Dustforce an experience that's larger than it's parts, a charming, sublime experience that respects the skill of whoever plays it without trying to intimidate you or restrict your experience.  Absolutely required.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												Pleasing to the eye, ear and mind, dustforce is a great platformer that will keep you sweeping for hours on end. -Gorgeous art style, full of charm and character with consistently themed levels with sprites to match. One of the things I love most about this game is the soundtrack, its mellow tones are relaxing and blend seamlessly with the gameplay, softening the frustration at my inept cleaning.  -Gameplay is consistently challenging, but as you repeat levels you gradually learn the layout and the best/fastest way to clear each and every obstacle. There is nothing more rewarding than when you get that perfect run (well, not perfect, but as good as I'm going to do). The momentum based character movement did take some getting used to, but after much practice it allows you to flit through a level like a breath of wind.-The main area in which Dustforce is lacking would be the tutorial, it provides a good basic understanding of the movement mechanics and will make a player reasonably competent. However, to play dustforce to its full, flowing potential it is a necessity to go on youtube and watch tutorials and examine the manouvres and tricks used by the best of the best.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												If you have a completionist personality and get addicted to things because of it, you will most certainly get your money's worth out of this game. There's no guarantee you'll enjoy it all, but at least you'll get your money's worth.Dustforce combines speedrunning and combat to create an intense "race against the clock" battle in each level. The basis is to clean up as much of the level as you can in order to advance on to the next levels, each one being more difficult than the last.This game prides itself in its level design, and therefore also in its aesthetics. Its levels, characters, enemies, and even movements are visually pleasing, which helps when you play the game for hours on end in order to beat it. The sound design is similar, having a bit of the "fresh" element to it in order to keep you from getting sick of playing. Secrets are also scattered around levels, awaiting the player's arrival to reveal themselves--and then unfortunately yield no product. All of this wrapped in a thoroughly-vetted world makes for an overall good game, worth the buy.However, if you're not a completionist, I would approach this purchase with caution. As I said before, because this is an extensive game with many, many levels, you'll get your money's worth, but only if you're able to play them. You can only advance on to the more difficult levels in this game if you beat the previous level well enough, and eventually this stops your progress entirely until you return to fully complete the previous levels (which can be extremely difficult later on). Most importantly, if you're not enjoying it, then you'll more than likely quit and never return. So, again, think well before buying it if you don't want to be completionist and then waste your money.(Also, there is a multiplayer function to this game, but I don't have friends who own the game so I can't say whether that's worth a try or not. Given the game's speed-combat combination, I imagine it would be fun but can't say for certain!)

Posted: April 21, 2014
												Dustforce is a non-linear action platformer, but it's split into levels. There are four main worlds that each hold different levels: some easy and fun, one beat down the enemies and some no-nonsence action. You can go to each of these worlds at any time you want, but some levels are locked. You get keys to unlock these locks by completing levels. The better you do on a level, the the more progress toward getting a key is made. So to unlock every single level, you have to get a perfect score (an SS in this case) on every level. That may seem very hard (and it is), but I've been having fun all the time trying to get a perfect score on every level no matter how long it takes me. I spent an hour or so trying to get one level down and I enjoyed every second of it (I still haven't SS'd that level). The gameplay is fun and makes you feel like awesome no matter how poorly you did on a level and the art style is amazing, as well as the music.

												As a general rule, if a game can really make me feel like a ninja, it is automatically good in my book. Great level design and controls make this game hit that mark; you'll be doing all kinds of fancy acrobatics easily. Thanks to the fact that a good score requires you to keep up a combo you'll also be doing it in one continuous string for the whole level, but almost never feeling like you're in a time crunch if you plan your route right.Other good points include: Great atmosphere, lots of secrets in both the levels and the hub (in fact you have to find most of the harder levels by exploring the hub), four different but balanced characters (all of whom can still beat every level), and the harder levels often make you think to solve them and can be quite difficult.

Posted: November 14, 2014
												So I got Dusforce about the time it came out or a little bit later...can't really remember and at the time I didn't invest alot of time into it, but having recently played a little of it and it being updated to DX, which adds new content, I decided to write this review. This game is one of those that have a really high skill cap and you will need to play it alot to master it and get the best times and scores, its in the Super Meat Boy Platformer category, one thing that is different is that you have to platform to get to the doors, which are level entry points and some of those doors are hard to get to so you actually need to be able to traverse the "level select" in order to complete all levels. There are a fair amount of levels, I'd say it would take 5-10hours max to beat all the levels(mostly because the end ones are hard and you will need to take alot of shots at them), but after you beat those you also have community created levels which are amazing and will keep you playing if you really want more. This game is a good bit of fun if you are into this type of games and an excellent purchase on sale, if you don't like the game I would still recommend the soundtrack because it is Phenomenal!

												This game is good. I'm not an enthusiast of the platformer genre, but I've enjoyed this game immensely. Within 24 hours of buying it, I'd already spent half of that time playing it. The levels are challenging, and you'll fail a lot, but that's part of the fun. The soundtrack keeps you relaxed all the way through, and it's an amazing listen even without the game. The devs hit the art style right on the mark, with the minimalist designs working with the gameplay to add some clarity to the scenes which are very nice to look at.Buy it. This game is underrated.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												This is an absolute gem! If you are the type that loves a challenge and enjoys platforming, this is a must-try game. This game is deceptively simple as there are a few sets of moves and mechanics that govern its world. But, as each level goes on, you start to use them in ways that did not seem apparent to keep your momentum.Some of the great features this game has are the quick-reset. Guys, you are likely to mess up, fail, over and over and OVER again with this. So have a quick-button reset is a great feature, especially for speed runner enthusiasts. This game is built to be played to ways, 1) complete the whole level with 100% finesse at the fastest time possible, or 2) reach the end of the level as quick as you can. Either way, there is something satisfying to both aims, and much more gratification once you see your name inch higher into the ranking boards.

YouTube™ Video: Underrated Games - Dustforce 

			Views: 77,271		

			After spending way longer than I expected with Dustforce I decided to lay down some thoughts on it. Some footage here is taken from the community replays, in those instances the player's name will be...		

------N with Donkey Kong Country 2 music.Indie platformer (THE PRESSES HAVE BEEN HALTED) about passing over specific spots and adminstering parental-style broom violence to enemies (who are sometimes tiny animals, you jerk.) No plot to follow. You have to 'SS' perfect each level to progress entirely, so you'll need more dedication than your megamans.The thing I enjoyed the most, is due to the generally sharp mechancis, there can be room to do suave recoveries. Lower ranked ss replays on the (well-implemented) leaderboards have been more mind-boggling because of this. However, there's many places that require pixel perfect actions (or some tricks, which are admittedly fun to figure out,) and the level designer has a habit of placing a cluster♥♥♥♥ of awkward near the end of a level. Slip up, and you're forced to restart. I spent 5 hours on one.But damn if that music doesn't keep you going.-And then I got calluses from a vido game for the first time.Basically, liked meat boy? Try this.

Posted: January 3, 2013
												An exceptionally chill platformer. The controls can be a hastle to get used to (I personally had to remap a few keys), but once you get a solid handle on it, speeding your way to a clean SS rank is greatly rewarding after your n-th try. One had better be ready to get good though, because the only way to progress to subsequent, more difficult levels is to get high ranks on the previous stages.Also the visuals are clean and crisp, and the soundtrack is definitely worth a listen.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												A game for competitive, experienced players, Dust Force combines the fast-paced action you'll get from a fighting game and combines it with a cinematic parkour experience that's perfect for speed-runners. With four characters to choose from, you'll be slowly migrating between these characters and learning how they work. Your first gold level you've unlocked will seem like a walk in the park once you're in the later stages. There's a ton of levels, a slew of hidden mechanics, easter eggs in seemingly all stages, a local multiplayer mode for up to four players, a fantastic level editor, and an experienced community filled with tons of downloadable maps.All in all, if you like fast-paced platformers involving wall-running, timers, an unforgettable soundtrack, and hidden mechanics, this is your game. Thumbs up.

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Great game, at first it may seem simple or easy, but the harder levels will make you want to tear your hair out trying to get that SS score. Great feature is that you can watch the runs of other players if you want to find an efficient way to beat a difficult part.Once you get a hang of the controlls, (I reccomend a game pad), the game is amazing and the sountrack and visuals are very chill, which helps because as I said it can get frustrating to make it through an entire level only to hit that spike right before the last piece of dust. If you like a challenge and have fast fingers than this game is for you.

Posted: January 21, 2012
												Highly difficult platformer in the vein of Super Meat Boy, but with much more fluid controls, an art style that's calming to the eyes, and a soundtrack so soothing that trying to beat a level for the hundredth time doesn't feel as frustrating as similar games, if at all. Best of all, it rewards skill: for each level you clear perfectly you gain a key which you can use to unlock a harder level of your choice, making it feel as though you're actually progressing. Unlike similar titles like I Wanna Be The Guy and the aforementioned Super Meat Boy, which tired me after a while and forced me to only play them in short bursts, Dustforce's aesthetic and clever level design kept me in a trance, encouraging me to play more, as if telling me that I'll always do better next time - and I did. Buy it. Now.

Posted: January 20, 2012
												I played and loved super meat boy. It was the hallmark of hardcore platformer when it was released but Dustforce is vastly superior in many ways. The gameplay is technical and deep. It takes a while to fully appreciate it and master it but when you have done it you realise that there is a flow in this game and a genius in the level design. I can go through a level just for the pleasure of following that flow and the music goes with it perfectly.It is a challenging game, very challenging in the end. If you can’t handle frustration it might not be for you but it is also rewarding if you can go through it.I can’t recommend it enough. It isn’t just the best hardcore platformer of all time it is also one of my favourite game period.

												Dustforce is the kind of platform game that requires determination, as you will have to play most of the levels several times before getting a rewarding Double S score, wondering which character would be the best for this level.There is no real time trial mode for the scoring system (the time you take only impacts the world ranking system): as long you don't break your Combo and clean the whole level, you will get your Double S score and be able to unlock new levels faster (that get quickly harder).And the soundtrack sets the mood, helping you to relax even though the new level you're trying to finish is hard as hell.Also, like most of this kind of platformer, you "should" really using a controller.

												THE SUCCESOR TO SUPER MEAT BOY. If you had a great time playing SMB, try this game. The cool thing is that you do not need a quick reaction that much, but rather a memorization of the level. The quick reaction comes in on what the next button needs to be pressed. Think Fighting games controls embedded in a very complex and fun platformer. "WHAT'S THAT SANVICH? PERFECTLY JUMP THEM ALL? GOOD IDEA!" - Heavy.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Dustforce is the most satisifiying platformer I have played in years, and heres why:Story: NA/10There is none.Gameplay: 9.8/10The gameplay is a mix of mirrors edge and janitorial duties, allowing your character to leap off the walls and traverse the enviroment in fluid, dynamic movement. It's nothing short of simply breathtaking, and looks just as good to watch as it is to play, but only slightly. Everything has this great sense of weight and momentum to it- your air dash is small, but builds momentum insanely quickly, sending you into top speed in a flash, running up walls is quick and sticky, meaning getting around on walls, ceilings and ramps is a breeze. The combat, while simple, serves as an excellent momentum booster. Smack an enemy in the air, and your air-dash or double jump becomes replenished, increasing your jump distance and allowing you to pull off some crazy crap. It's utterly fantastic.Graphics: 8/10They're simple, stylish and beautiful. The leaves, slime, dust and trash all liven up the levels, and even suggest where to go next. They add a lot of charm.Music: 8.2/10Great to listen to in and out of Dustforce, and is relaxing enough to not make you frustrated.Overall: 8.6

Posted: June 21, 2014
												This is an absolute gem! If you are the type that loves a challenge and enjoys platforming, this is a must-try game. This game is deceptively simple as there are a few sets of moves and mechanics that govern its world. But, as each level goes on, you start to use them in ways that did not seem apparent to keep your momentum.Some of the great features this game has are the quick-reset. Guys, you are likely to mess up, fail, over and over and OVER again with this. So have a quick-button reset is a great feature, especially for speed runner enthusiasts. This game is built to be played to ways, 1) complete the whole level with 100% finesse at the fastest time possible, or 2) reach the end of the level as quick as you can. Either way, there is something satisfying to both aims, and much more gratification once you see your name inch higher into the ranking boards.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												An amazingly smooth and chill platforming game with insanely good music, pleasing visuals and excellent level design that runs butter smooth on almost any machine. The focus here is mechanics, which are all well implemented, and once you master the basics movements and learn how the dash can be used, it opens up a whole new world of possibilities.Some levels can be very frustrating at first, no doubt about it, but the aforementioned great music can keep you calm for long periods of time. The immensely satisfying feeling of seeing an SS ranking and a good time on the end screen after working hard to get there makes this such an easy title to recommend. It's time trial without the stress.The flow of movements and consistence is more important here than in other platformers, and these are probably the defining properties of Dustforce. There's never a time where you'll get lucky, and perfect a level, and there are few random elements in the game. Being able to see records of other players and friends can help you improve by a ton, and gives you something to strive for.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												Dustforce is the kind of game I want to get good at, and feel like I am, until I see my rankings on the leaderboards. Mechanically, I haven't played a platformer that responds so well. Once you wrestle out the way to bind your keys to your gamepad, prepare to be blown away by the insane amount of love put in to make this godly platformer. Gameplay and animation is insanely fluid, and while controls can be a bit floaty, they lend themselves well to the levels designed around it, and gives generous space failure, even when your inner speed demon does not. This game must be noted as one without any notable story, and is built solely around replay value, so if you're like me and enjoy a veil of plot to your games, you won't find it here. Honestly, with how much the game screams of personality, and with all the bear-cleaning and animal smacking, I felt like there was a missed opportunity in set up, but this is not a detractor. There is a lot of humor to be found in just the enviornment, and like any good p0rn, you're not here for the story. Wonderful game if you want to feel inferior and still have a great time.

Posted: March 9, 2012
												Another beautiful indie game!  Last year it was Jamestown for me, this year it might well be Dustforce.This is a great looking, acrobatic/ninja-rific platformer with a chilled out electronic score and a nice scaling difficultly level.  Imagine Meatboy, but way less frustrating and soul-crushingly difficult, plus more move variety, and rewarding combat. (!)While levels can be beat without necessarily being an ace player, for me there's a strong, strong "I know I can do better" urge after completing a run, so there's a lot of value here if you're a perfectionist.  And the game's beautiful graphics, balletic animations and excellent level design always reward me for coming back to previous challenges.Lastly, the ability to watch replays of the top players is also an excellent addition, both to help you see how others solved tricky spots and to help you improve your game.This is a real gem, grab it if you like platformers with style!EDIT: I've enjoyed my time with Dust Force, but unforunately I feel like I've hit the skill ceiling.  I've gotten to a point in the levels where I'm just not good enough to progress further, and don't think it's worth my entertainment time to put in the hours to get better.  This in NO WAY is the fault of the game or it's developers.  I still think Dust Force is amazing, but unfortunately I just won't be able to crack open its higher level content.

												If you haven't already gotten this game...Do so now. It's an amazing game. I mean, come on, you're playing Acrobatic Ninja Janitors! I mean...Come on, you TOTALLY don't see this kind of thing happen everyday. This game is totally worth the money. And at a low price too. You'd be a damn fool not to buy it while it's hot. Posted: May 29, 2012
												Dustforce is a challenging action arcade platformer in the same vein as Super Meat Boy.  The graphics are serviceable, and the music is exceptionally well done.  I appreciate the fact that the developers attempted to harken back to old style 8-bit audio without actually giving us the terribly awful reality of it (like in Wizorb).  Though the game does work with the Steam Overlay and supports widescreen, the gamepad support is not very well implemented and will require the player to manually reconfigure the control scheme to work.  I found the the native keyboard controls to be cramped and non-intuitive, particularly for a game that requires fast reflexes.  Other users on the forums have reported they prefer the keyboard for later in the game, but I have not progressed far enough to have an opinion one way or another.  Dustforce in short, is a quality indie game that will resonate with fans of Super Meat Boy or VVVVVVvvvvVVVV.

Posted: November 29, 2012
												Get a frickin controller, sit down, and prepare for an awesome platoformer. The goal of this game is to remove all the dust and dust monsters, and while that sounds like the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ idea in human history, this game is 78 kinds of epic. By using various forms of wall jumping, wall running, ceiling jumping, ceiling running, mid-air jumps, mid-air hit multipiers, and etc., you end up feeling like spider-man on cocaine as you bounce around levels "dusting" things up. Posted: January 20, 2012
												What happens when someone wants to make a game about janitors with the control scheme of Megaman Zero and a pinch of Sonic the Hedgehog's speed? We get Dustforce.Each of the game's "worlds" contain plenty of pre-unlocked levels to master as you meander your way through them one after another to unlock the rest of the more challenging and meaty ones. Posted: March 6, 2016
												~~My first review~~  Let me first explain my negative review. Ultimately, I wouldn't recommend this game to myself. Rather, I would recommend Dustforce to masochists, personal enemies, and professional platform gamers. I really wanted to like Dustforce. The promo videos made it seem like one casually 'ninjas' and floats about beautiful 16 bit levels collecting cobwebs like Sonic collects rings. Not quite. The concept itself is interesting. The goal is to travel through obstical courses as fast as possible. Along the way, you must run through patches of dust and hit "enemies" in order to clear the level. This is a 2D speed-running game.  The physics and mechanics make absolutely no sense to the uninitiated casual game playing plebian like myself. It can be frustrating, repetative and time consuming simply jumping from platform to platform in the overworld. This is where you wander around finding doors to unlock, which represent individual levels. Compare with titles like Super Meat Boy and Cave Story. These games present challenging and interesting game play, while having control schemes and movement that are predictable and intuitive. Dustforce DX creates simple levels, that are made challenging by a character that is difficult to control. Essentially, they took a relatively simple concept and made it difficult to enjoy on account of sloppy, tendinitis aggravating controls that are frustrating to learn and maddening to master. Further, the actual levels are fairly uninteresting and easy to get through. The challenge is that in order to properly complete a level, simply getting through it is not enough. You need to get the fastest time possible without missing any dust. This means repeating levels until you have every move perfected. This ends up being more busy work than anything else. You could easily spend a thousand hours trying to perfect each level. Combined with controls that assault your hands, it can be a very unforgiving process of which I quickly grew tired. I suppose in the Genre of repetitive games which slap you around and demand perfection it succeeds. However, I guess I'm not a fan of games where developers decided the best way to make a game challenging is to make the character barely controllable. I feel like back in the days of original 8 bit graphic platformers, this would simply be called bad controls and it would be relegated to 2 and 3 star reviews. These days there are gamers who specifically enjoy and excel at games with lousy controls, and I suspect if you're one of those people you will find a lot of fun in spending countless hours punishing yourself on Dustforce.  Recall the viral flash game where the object is to control a sprinters limbs to push him over the finish line, or rather see how far you can comically stumble and hobble across a track. This is the same concept taken to it's inevitable extreme... OK, it's not THAT bad, but you'll be spending a half hour trying to jump onto a ledge just to get to another stage... only to discover that you don't have the key to unlock it. Oh right, keys. In order to unlock all the levels, you will need to complete the stages with perfect scores to accumulate keys. Ugh. Summary; If you are considering using the standard keyboard layout, either get an ice pack for your hands or forget about it. The game is barely playable on a game-pad, which is far superior to the keyboard controls. If you're a demi-god with spaghetti fingers and the ability to pick up outrageous controls, and have a lot of time and patience, I guess you will LOVE this game. If you're a casual gamer who likes simple controls, and doesn't want to invest the hours it will take to teach your hands to waltz like noodles through endlessly repetitive levels of dust ninja then get Super Meat Boy instead.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												I did not know what to expect when I started this game. But I can say that I was pleasantly surprised. Within Dustforce DX is some of the most precise, well-constructed 2D platforming that you can experience. Its unique concept and fair set-up allows you to enjoy the game, no matter what your skill level. This is especially true provided the time and score system. If I were to provide a negative quirk, it would be the key system and hub which is not entirely user-friendly, and does become a bit of a hassle when transversing from stage-to-stage. Otherwise, it is a fun experience and I would recommend it for anyone who enjoys a challenging 2D platformer.

Posted: January 31, 2012
												Yet another new Indie precision platformer is born.  Dustforce reminds me of the days of Shinobi 3, and a few other platformers with ninja-like moves.  It's got tight controls, and will keep you repeating levels to get a higher score worthy enough to be in the top of the leaderboards.  Higher scores also give you more keys to open new, harder levels.  The best things I like about this game is the ambient chill soundtrack - which I haven't heard in a game for a long time - and the ability to playback the videos of any player from the leaderboard.  This should help first-timers understand the game system and best lines when tackling the stages.  Highly recommended for above-average skilled platform gamers only.

Posted: June 16, 2014
												I have a♥♥♥♥♥♥load of hours in this game, so there may or may not be a hint of bias here.I ♥♥♥♥ing love Dustforce. Probably the biggest challenge, aside from the hardest levels in this game, is getting the hang of the controls. It takes a special amount of dedication to truly master the techniques and proper methods to control your character. I played the game for a pretty decent amount of time (10 or more hours?) and I kind of stopped playing at a certain point. It wasn't until I came back into the game that I found a control scheme that actually worked for me, and went on to complete most of the levels in their entirety. Fast forward to the time I wrote this review and I have over 400 hours put into the game. Oops.So you're probably wondering "Bbop, how the hell did you manage to get 400+ hours into this game and never truly 100% beat the game?" Well, to tell the truth, most of my hours spent on this game doesn't even come from playing the main levels.atlas.dustforce.com gives you a massive archive of user-created levels. I've also spent a LOT of time creating my own levels! I would recommend checking my stuff out whenever you get the chance. ;)Dustforce might just have some of the best level-editing tools a platformer could ever give you. I know this because I've spent about as much time making Dustforce maps as I have playing them.Also time-attacking both custom and vanilla maps is addicting as hell, since every map in the game AND every map that gets published on the Atlas has their own leaderboard. The best part about the leaderboards is that they save replays of each run so you get so see how the game's most dedicated players got such amazing times.So yeah, is it the best platformer ever? I would say no - I honestly have no idea - but it is surely the most addicting one I've ever played. Atlas gives Dustforce a near-infinite amount of replayability, whether you like designing levels or playing and reviewing them... or both. o_oWow I can't believe I wrote a review this long. Most of my reccomendations are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ jokes, but there you go.

This should help first-timers understand the game system and best lines when tackling the stages.  Highly recommended for above-average skilled platform gamers only.

Posted: March 6, 2016
												~~My first review~~  Let me first explain my negative review. Ultimately, I wouldn't recommend this game to myself. Rather, I would recommend Dustforce to masochists, personal enemies, and professional platform gamers. I really wanted to like Dustforce. The promo videos made it seem like one casually 'ninjas' and floats about beautiful 16 bit levels collecting cobwebs like Sonic collects rings. Not quite. The concept itself is interesting. The goal is to travel through obstical courses as fast as possible. Along the way, you must run through patches of dust and hit "enemies" in order to clear the level. This is a 2D speed-running game.  The physics and mechanics make absolutely no sense to the uninitiated casual game playing plebian like myself. It can be frustrating, repetative and time consuming simply jumping from platform to platform in the overworld. This is where you wander around finding doors to unlock, which represent individual levels. Compare with titles like Super Meat Boy and Cave Story. These games present challenging and interesting game play, while having control schemes and movement that are predictable and intuitive. Dustforce DX creates simple levels, that are made challenging by a character that is difficult to control. Essentially, they took a relatively simple concept and made it difficult to enjoy on account of sloppy, tendinitis aggravating controls that are frustrating to learn and maddening to master. Further, the actual levels are fairly uninteresting and easy to get through. The challenge is that in order to properly complete a level, simply getting through it is not enough. You need to get the fastest time possible without missing any dust. This means repeating levels until you have every move perfected. This ends up being more busy work than anything else. You could easily spend a thousand hours trying to perfect each level. Combined with controls that assault your hands, it can be a very unforgiving process of which I quickly grew tired. I suppose in the Genre of repetitive games which slap you around and demand perfection it succeeds. However, I guess I'm not a fan of games where developers decided the best way to make a game challenging is to make the character barely controllable. I feel like back in the days of original 8 bit graphic platformers, this would simply be called bad controls and it would be relegated to 2 and 3 star reviews. These days there are gamers who specifically enjoy and excel at games with lousy controls, and I suspect if you're one of those people you will find a lot of fun in spending countless hours punishing yourself on Dustforce.  Recall the viral flash game where the object is to control a sprinters limbs to push him over the finish line, or rather see how far you can comically stumble and hobble across a track. This is the same concept taken to it's inevitable extreme... OK, it's not THAT bad, but you'll be spending a half hour trying to jump onto a ledge just to get to another stage... only to discover that you don't have the key to unlock it. Oh right, keys. In order to unlock all the levels, you will need to complete the stages with perfect scores to accumulate keys. Ugh. Summary; If you are considering using the standard keyboard layout, either get an ice pack for your hands or forget about it. The game is barely playable on a game-pad, which is far superior to the keyboard controls. If you're a demi-god with spaghetti fingers and the ability to pick up outrageous controls, and have a lot of time and patience, I guess you will LOVE this game. If you're a casual gamer who likes simple controls, and doesn't want to invest the hours it will take to teach your hands to waltz like noodles through endlessly repetitive levels of dust ninja then get Super Meat Boy instead.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												I'm keeping this simple, if you like platformers that have a good sense of flow, this game is for you. It's easy to pick up yet difficult to master, as any good game should be. As an added bonus, the soundtrack is excellent and certainly contributes to the overall sense of flow you get from this game.

Posted: November 14, 2014
												This game is beautiful. I often get utterly lost in it and forget that I'm playing a game. The soundtrack consistently completely engrosses me. The gameplay is so enjoyable throughout the game. The visual aesthetic is absolutely wonderful. The overworld is designed perfectly for easing players into the more advanced levels, although in the DX update, it's much harder to unlock the harder levels. Every level, despite most using one of four visual styles, is very memorable. Now: a quick warning. This game can eat up a ton of time on a few levels as the hard levels are very hard. I have almost no background in platforming, so maybe i just suck, but I still can't beat Backup Shift. Be prepared for very exact platforming.This game is basically perfect. Even any glitches are just really cool. Get it, people.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												If you like a challenge, this is a game for you. The levels start off easy to get you used to the controls but they ramp up in difficulty quickly. But the best part is that it's all fair. No random disappearing blocks, falling spikes or anything of the sort. If you mess up, it's all on you. You'll find yourself grinding a hard level for hours to get SS rank without it really feeling like a grind and it'll all be worth it when you get it.There's also a level editor with a huge amount of user created levels on the Atlas in case you want more challenges and neat ideas you wouldn't see in the stock levels.One of my favourite features though is the leaderboard/replay system. Every run automatically gets recorded and uploaded to the boards so you can view anyone's run at any time (as long as you have an internet connection of course). No need to wonder how the world record got such a crazy time, you can just view it yourself! It really pushes you to improve yourself and compete with your friends.You can easily put in a lot of hours so it's an absolute bargain for the price, especially since it regularly goes on a deep sale.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												I love this game to death, but it's frankly kind of hard to recommend to a lot of people. It's definitely for those who want to MASTER a game. It's a speed runner's dream. It gets hard as hell eventually, but I've found that with enough practice I've done what I thought was impossible. The soundtrack is pure distilled chilled love. The feeling of control in this game is pretty weird. I want to say they're fluid, but it has a handful of quirks, I've played enough of the game that I don't notice any more. If you want a platforming challenge, get Dustforce. It feels great when you get the flow of it.

Posted: January 1
Product received for free
												What a cool little game. It's a runner-platformer where you have to reach the end of the stage cleaning all sorts of dirt/slime/dust in the way. The animation is VERY well done and the level design is great to put all of your ninja/dusting skills into use. The soundtrack is noteworthy as well. I just didn't notice any difference between the 4 cleaners (if there's any at all) and there's not too many levels, though there's a level editor if you feel like giving it a shot. I recommend playing it with a controller, but you will have to manually map it in the options menu. If you don't want to, you can enjoy it with the keyboard as well, the controls are very responsive.
